column4: I took classes one summer and regretted not having a break the next fall
column5: but YMMV.

column4: Keep in mind
column5: as you are weighing options
column6: that there are summer terms that are HALF terms (Spring Term
column7: and Summer Term) and there's a summer term that is a normal full term (Spring/Summer Term).    ​  Why this matters?  It means that if you only enrolled in one half-term
column8: you would still have a summer break
column9: just a shorter one.  It also matters because in the half-terms
column10: classes only meet for 7 weeks so they may meet more often (i.e. daily) or for longer.  Some students like that
column11: others don't--and some classes may be easier or harder in that structure.  You may learn/retain more when you're hitting the material every day--but you have little turnaround time for homework assignments.     Not a lot of undergrads take Spring/Summer (the whole term) so I assume there are limited offerings.  I don't know if that's driven by low demand (few students want to sign away their whole summer) or low supply (not so many faculty want to sign away their whole summer) or some combo.  Anyway
column12: people who DO want to have a super productive summer in terms of credits could take classes in both half terms.    ​  (apologies if you already know all this -- might be helpful for others)

column4: Donâ€™t do so much. Iâ€™ve taken different classes in the summer and generally they are a lot of work. The material is a lot more condensed so it takes twice as much time per day than usual. I think stats 250 is good for spring/summer. Not sure I can recommend chem 210/211 for the shorter semester tho. I think youâ€™ll gain value from a more normal pace. Orgo takes time to fully under and appreciate the methodology so I think itâ€™s better to do those during normal semesters. Idk anything about Econ

column4: I used to run the lab for 463 years back so the curriculum may have changed since then
column5: but at the time Linear Algebra was not required. You'll get into phase planes
column6: eigenvalues/vectors (including building and solving Jacobian matrices)
column7: and some introduction to bifurcations but if you understand those concepts at a high level already you should be in good shape.  Linear Algebra is listed as a recommended prereq for many 400 level math classes but I actually finished my Math Bio major without ever taking it (though missing that class made for a rude awakening in some of the other more proof-based 400 and 500 level courses).

column4: I took Math 463
column5: there were definitely some concepts of linear algebra that would be difficult to get by without in the first half of the course
column6: but in the second half you would be fine. Was your DiffEq class purely DiffEq
column7: or did you cover some linear algebra?

column4: Hi everyone

column6: which one was more difficult? (Mcdb 310 v. BIO 305)  Note: Pre- PA BHS major and I kind of hate math and chem (hated chem 210) so I'm scared of biochem  Thanks!!

column4: Bio305 fersure
I took both in summer. I feel like personally I preferred biochem to genetics just because I donâ€™t like math ðŸ˜‚ and genetics had more math / calculations

I took genetics last summer and biochem last fall (so both were online). I'd recommend taking genetics in the summer.  I think genetics is usually easier in the summer compared to the school year (there are more non-exam points available during the summer term
column5: like homework/projects/daily quizzes). I didn't really enjoy it though--having dense 2-hour lecture videos Mon/Tues/Weds plus 3 zoom discussions a week felt like a drag. Probability and statistics are the only math in genetics (think Hardy-Weinberg and Punnett Squares).  Biochem wasn't my favorite subject either
column6: but it's definitely way more bio-heavy than chem. It's like Bio 172 with more content. You usually won't have to cover mechanisms
column7: and you won't need any of the reagents or reaction types taught in orgo. Instead
column8: you'll be learning lots of enzyme names and functions. If you can
column9: try waiting until things are in-person to take it--although it's memorization-heavy and you can control-f things while it's online
column10: the online exams are designed to be open-book with lots of select-all-that-apply questions.

Overall this is a good thing. This is the first mass-vaccination campaign in history with equity as a first-class principle. That is a very hard problem and necessarily means you will reallocate supply as you bring online additional resources to reach underserved populations (for example
column5: ramping up volunteers to run clinics in poor neighborhoods).  Also
column6: since we are all wondering â€œwhen will I get offered the vaccine?â€
column7: Iâ€™d note this has nothing to do with overall supply
column8: which is still ramping up. These day-to-day headlines on supply and demand do not accurately illustrate the fundamentals that have remained unchanged since December - we will have *at least* 200 million doses in the US by end of March and *at least* 400 million by June. Itâ€™s very likely the primary problem of vaccine distribution will become demand rather than supply in the next 2-3 months.  Edit: wow
column9: multiple downvotes in the first 10 minutes! Iâ€™d appreciate if someone could tell me why. Do yâ€™all really think the best way to ensure equity for vaccine access is to make vulnerable people in Detroit and Flint drive an hour to U-M Hospital rather than bringing the supply to them? Or do you doubt that Pfizer and Moderna are going to fulfill their federal contracts? [Pfizer is actually running ahead of schedule](https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.cnbc.com/amp/2021/02/02/covid-vaccine-pfizer-plans-to-deliver-200-million-doses-to-us-by-may-sooner-than-expected.html) and [hereâ€™s an editorial by a former FDA commissioner](https://www.wsj.com/articles/what-to-do-when-theres-a-covid-19-vaccine-glut-11612732696?redirect=amp#click=https://t.co/tTVQ5qfiz9) making the point that supply is going to improve soon and so we need to be preparing for a demand problem *now*.

column4: After reading the article
column5: this doesn't affect students as much as the headline wants you to believe.   Basically
column6: the total number of vaccinations hasn't been reduced
column7: but previously UM medicine was the primary source of distribution
column8: meaning that everyone who wanted to get the vaccine had to come to UM medicine.      With this new allocation method
column9: the vaccine is being decentralized to more local areas. Instead of the people coming for the vaccine
column10: the vaccine is coming to them
column11: which is much better from a health perspective and an accessibility standpoint. Many people can't take the time to drive to Ann arbor to get a vaccine
column12: or they may not have access to a car.      On top of that
column13: it's restructuring the vaccine schedule somewhat. While covid is disproportionately affecting elderly people
column14: it's also disproportionally affecting poorer people. The more vulnerable populations should get the vaccine sooner
column15: as they are at higher risk of infection and morbidity.      From a student perspective
column16: this has very little impact on us because we were last in line anyway.      But with current production and Pfizer trying to [reduce vaccine production time](https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/pfizer-hopes-cut-vaccine-manufacturing-time-almost-half-n1257069) it is likely everyone will get vaccines ahead of current projections.

column4: Umich sent me an email saying **How to Communicate Your Continued Interest in the University of Michigan** but also said **We are certain we have enough information at this time to make a decision** in the same email. What does this even mean? does every applicant get this email? (btw i applied rd)
My understanding is that:  1) They have everything they need for a decision right now
column5: but;  2) They want you to confirm that Umich is still your first choice
column6: and you will be attending should you be accepted.  This is a time-saving thing for them. It's basically an unofficial guarantee for them that the people they accept will go to their school instead of another institution. If people communicate they are no longer interested (e.g.
column7: they were accepted to their preferred school)
column8: then they won't waste anymore time on that application. By contrast
column9: if someone says they *are* still interested in attending
column10: that will be weighed in against people who may not have replied.  Go through their provided outlet and let them know you have continued interest and that Umich is your first choice.

column4: [deleted]
It sounds to me like you either didn't finish your application or haven't committed to attending in some way that they have asked you to.
Could anyone recommend places to live during the fall 2021 semester as a junior international exchange student? (party friendly places please)

there is a facebook group [here](https://www.facebook.com/groups/223351171575348/?multi_permalinks=849574745619651) for subletting and leasing apartments/houses primarily for umich students. Most of the stuff I see on there is people trying to sublet their place for a few months or a semester
column5: you shold check it out.

column4: Depending on which country you are coming from
column5: if there are sufficiently many students from your country and they have a student org on campus you can mail them to see if someone is willing to host you. Usually international student communities stick together and there is always someone from the organization willing to help

column4: party friendly and exchange student sounds like a perfect fit at truth co-op!! the website is www.icc.coop
column5: and they have a youtube video here that gives a tour
column6: https://youtu.be/UHIWAgJOsXA  truth is themed for international students but is normally a 50/50 of umich student and international/exchange students. itâ€™s big enough to find a calm atmosphere but also have a lot of people around if you wanna talk to them! I believe they do fall only contracts as well :)

column4: I was at the commencement. The security was crazy.  The Secret Service was on all the highway over passes. There were snipers up above the luxury boxes. They put dump trucks around the stadium as a barricade. Obama looked like an ant from way up in my seats. I guess it was him at least.
now show the line for the dining halls during the first week of classes last semester
I was there booya! Got bronchitis from sleeping in those cold streets but it was worth it!
I stood in that line!
Looks like the line for popeyes

This was not for Obama speaking at commencement in 2010.  [This line is for when Obama spoke on campus in 2012](https://www.michiganradio.org/post/ann-arbor-thousands-wait-line-tickets-see-obama).  For reference Obama @ commencement  wasn't announced until April of that year; you can very clearly see this is the winter.  [Here's the Ann Arbor news with images from that date](http://www.annarbor.com/news/the-line-for-graduation-tickets/); you can see grass and green in the background.  There's no way this is in April in Michigan.
I remember going to this
\*CORRECTION\* This was the line for when Obama gave a speech on campus April 2
